Environment  On the basis of the environmental assessment of the proposed Balochistan 
Assessment  Devolved Social Services Program (BDSSP), the program loan is classified 
as  environmental  category  B.  Most  of  the  policy  actions  will  lead  to 
substantial  positive  environmental  impacts.  Any  potential  negative 
environmental impacts that may have resulted from increased expenditure 
in the water supply and sanitation (WSS) and health sectors have been 
adequately addressed. 
   
Program  The  proposed  BDSSP  comprises  two  program  loans,  an  Asian 
Description  Development Fund (ADF) grant for the control of human immunodeficiency 
  virus/acquired  immunodeficiency  syndrome  (HIV/AIDS)  and  infectious 
diseases, and a technical assistance (TA) loan. The Program will support 
policy  reforms  to  improve  education,  health,  and  WSS;  finance  social 
sector performance grants to the districts; support capacity building and 
institutional strengthening for social service delivery in both provinces and 
districts; empower citizens to play a greater role in social service delivery; 
and enable the private sector to participate in public and private social 
service delivery.  
   
Rationale  Balochistan’s social sector indicators are among the most challenging in 
  South Asia: female primary school enrollment, for example, is just above 
20%.  Balochistan  province  remains  largely  untouched  by  the  buoyant 
economic growth witnessed in the past few years in Pakistan. Balochistan 
is the country’s largest province, with nearly 44% of its surface area and a 
thinly  dispersed  population  of  around  6.5  million.  The  rugged  and 
inaccessible terrain, limited water resources for irrigation, large illiterate 
population,  ethnic  diversity,  and  traditional  women’s  status  are  added 
challenges to economic growth and human development in Balochistan. 
Many of these factors increase the cost of providing social services in 
Balochistan.  The  predominantly  agro-pastoral  economy  and  severe 
droughts in the last decade have led to internal migration and increased the 
vulnerability of the poor and the women. Overexploitation of groundwater, 
the  rapid  disappearance  of  traditional  surface  water  sources,  and  the 
limited harvesting of surface water have further aggravated water scarcity.  
 
Human capital must rapidly improve for Balochistan to tap internal and 
external  markets,  and  capitalize  on  market-driven  economic  growth.

iv         
 
Balochistan  has  made  some  progress  in  its  education  and  health 
indicators;  but  the  interplay  of  geographic,  cultural,  ethnic,  historical, 
political, and other factors poses governance and institutional challenges 
with major implications for the quality of social service delivery. Balochistan 
needs to implement governance reforms and strengthen institutions in the 
social  sector  to  improve  the  effectiveness  of  public  and  private  social 
service delivery.  
 
The government of Balochistan is determined to pursue a robust economic 
and  human  development  path,  as  stated  in  the  Balochistan  Poverty 
Reduction Strategy Paper (BPRSP). However, it has limited resources and 
flexibility to support its development needs. Large stocks of high-interest 
debt and constrained fiscal space have limited the scope for financing 
human development in Balochistan. 
 
The  challenging  social  sector  indicators,  challenges  in  social  service 
provision, and low current investments in the social sectors justify need for 
higher  investments  and  more  efficiency  in  the  social  sectors.  The 
Balochistan  Local  Government  Ordinance  (BLGO)  2001  has  created 
institutional opportunities to improve social service delivery by involving 
local governments and communities. However, policy reforms, institutional 
strengthening,  and  capacity  building  of  both  managers  and  service 
providers are needed to improve devolved social services. 
   
Impact and  BDSSP  will  help  Balochistan  province  accelerate  progress  toward  the 
Outcomes  Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and BPRSP goals in education, 
  health, and WSS. The objectives of BDSSP are to (i) improve access to 
affordable, efficient, effective, and good-quality education, health, and WSS 
in the public and private sectors; (ii) decrease inequities in social services 
based on income, gender, ethnicity, and geography; and (iii) strengthen 
local governments, the private sector, and communities to improve social 
service delivery. 
 
The  program  has  four  principal  policy  areas:  (i)  provincial  efficiency 
incentives, to strengthen and clarify relationships between provincial and 
local governments; (ii) managerial power, to strengthen the relationship 
between  the  local  governments  and  the  providers  of  social  services; 
(iii) citizen voice and empowerment, to strengthen the relationship between 
citizens and policy makers, and between citizens and service providers; 
and (iv) private sector engagement in service delivery. 
 
BDSSP will provide policy reform support for province-wide devolved social 
services (education, health, and WSS) through performance grants and 
TA.  The  Balochistan  Performance  Grant  Rules  2005  define  the 
implementation arrangements, procedures, and monitoring and reporting 
channels for the performance grants to be supported by BDSSP. 
   
Cost Estimates  The additional costs associated with policy and institutional reforms, and 
  measures to expedite progress toward education, health, and WSS–related 
MDGs, are estimated to be at least $261 million equivalent.

Program  The BDSSP interventions will further Balochistan’s progress toward the

Beneficiaries   
  BDSSP will increase funding for social services through performance grant 
transfers and additional support for current expenditures. The performance 
grants are designed to enable local governments to provide a flexible, 
needs-based  response  to  local  conditions,  adopt  an  effective  demand-
driven  and  participatory  planning  process  to  identify  service  gaps,  and 
rationalize and develop services with full ownership of the interventions 
decided by them. At the same time, the grants target priority investments in 
the social sectors according to the provincial policy frameworks to ensure 
balanced progress in an accelerated manner toward the MDGs and the 
BDSSP policy reforms. The additional support for current expenditures will 
help bridge critical gaps in non-salary expenditures in the social sectors. 
 
Performance grant funding to local governments for basic social services 
and  the  introduction  of  a  package  of  minimum  essential  services  will 
particularly  benefit  the  poor  and  vulnerable.  The  TA  will  assist  the 
government of Balochistan in developing a strategy and action plan to

ix
promote  public-private  partnership  (PPP)  in  social  service  delivery; 
innovating  improvements  in  the  quality,  access,  and  delivery  of  social 
services; and evolving and implementing a self-regulatory mechanism for 
the private sector. While programs such as BDSSP cannot directly address 
the  issue  of  retrogressive  societal  norms  and  practices,  which  cause 
women  to  be  marginalized  in  Balochistan  society,  they  can  certainly 
improve the quality of women’s lives and lay the groundwork for greater 
autonomy for women in both public and private spheres. 
 
BDSSP will strengthen the local government system. Its policy reforms will 
assist the government of Balochistan in defining the role of the provincial 
social sector departments according to BLGO 2001. The program will help 
build the capacity of local councilors, including women councilors, to plan, 
implement, and manage improvements in service delivery, and will provide 
linkages with related activities that are ongoing. In addition, the program 
will  further  institutionalize  the  involvement  of  the  community  and  civil 
society in local government affairs. 
 
Poverty in Balochistan is also marked by a general sense of powerlessness 
and a perceived lack of dignity. While BDSSP cannot directly address the 
governance issues that give rise to and perpetuate such feelings, program 
initiatives aimed at removing inequities and ensuring that public services 
are managed by, and in consultation with, elected representatives and 
community members can help reduce apathy and insecurity among the 
vulnerable in Balochistan. 
   
Risks and  The  success  of  the  program  is  subject  to  a  number  of  risks  and 
Assumptions  assumptions. Appropriate risk mitigation measures have been integrated 
  into the program design, and are discussed below. 
 
The  government  has  a  wide  constituency  to  satisfy  and  is  therefore 
vulnerable  to  different  pressures.  The  porous  borders  with  neighboring 
countries allow rampant smuggling. Law enforcement is handicapped by 
separate but coexisting rules and enforcement systems in some parts of 
the province. The vast size and rugged terrain of the province and the 
sparse,  poorly  connected  population  make  administration  all  the  more 
difficult. BDSSP cannot mitigate all these risks, particularly those related to 
geopolitics. But it will help mitigate some risks and would link with ongoing 
efforts in this regard under BRMP, DSP, Access to Justice Program, and 
other programs. 
 
There  is  a  risk  that  vested  interests  might  be  resistant  to  the  new 
transparent and accountable processes and reluctant to change systems. 
To  mitigate  such  risks,  high-level  support  and  a  high-level  steering 
committee will be important. Risks are expected to be further mitigated 
through such BDSSP policy actions as special audits, public availability of 
accounts and expenditures, and public grievance mechanisms. A major 
focus of BDSSP is improving social sector governance, and establishing 
transparent and objective decision-making to minimize rent seeking. The 
implementation of reforms might therefore be delayed or undermined by 
vested interests. BDSSP will counter such risks by building stakeholder

x         
 
ownership  during  program  design  and  implementation,  establishing 
program  oversight  mechanisms  including  the  participation  of  local 
government council committees, and ensuring synergy with other reform 
programs. 
 
Fast-track devolution has brought with it a substantial agenda of political, 
administrative, and fiscal restructuring; new systems, rules, and guidelines; 
and the need to train administrators and councilors. Local government 
systems  must  be  fully  operational  and  government  departments  and 
agencies geared to fully support the process. A major concern is the limited 
actual devolution of financial, managerial, and technical responsibilities and 
the inadequate capacity of local government functionaries. These risks will 
be mitigated by rationalizing the roles and responsibilities of the provincial 
departments  in  the  light  of  their  changed  relationship  with  the  local 
governments under BLGO 2001, and building local government capacity 
under the TA Loan. 
 
Pakistan’s  macroeconomic  parameters  have  been  strong  in  the  past 
few  years  and  policy  reforms  are  beginning  to  show  positive  results. 
However, poverty remains unacceptably high and cannot be allowed to 
stay that way. The country is highly vulnerable to external shocks. To 
mitigate  such  risks  as  far  as  possible,  Pakistan  has  put  in  place  a 
consistent economic management strategy to reduce debt and help ensure 
fiscal  stability.  The  government  of  Balochistan,  with  BRMP  support,  is 
developing its own debt management strategy.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) two proposed 
program  loans,  (ii)  a  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  loan,  and  (iii)  a  proposed  Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) grant—all to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Balochistan 
Devolved Social Services Program (BDSSP).1 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Pakistan’s macroeconomic situation has improved significantly in the last few years. 
Before the 1990s, external capital flows drove gross domestic product (GDP) growth rates of 
6%, causing major structural imbalances in public finance. The rapid accumulation of debt led to 
serious  fiscal  constraints  in  the  1990s:  average  GDP  growth  declined  to  4.4%  and 
unemployment rose from 4.7% in fiscal year (FY) 1993 to 7.8% in FY2000.2 Since FY2000, 
however, the overall economy and fiscal balance have improved, and economic performance 
continues to show strength—macroeconomic fundamentals are better than at any time in the 
past decade. In FY2005, GDP growth was 8.4% (compared with 6.4% in FY2004), the highest 
in the last two decades. But the fiscal deficit has also grown to 3.2% of GDP in FY2005 from 
2.3% of GDP the previous year. 
 
3.  In FY2006, GDP growth is likely to be broad-based and is expected to be more than 
7%, while the fiscal deficit will remain below 4%. The medium-term prospects for the Pakistan 
economy continue to improve, but sustained economic recovery is subject to certain risks. 
There are early signs of overheating—inflation rose to 9.3% in FY2005. Imports are expanding 
rapidly, from 15.6% in FY2004 to more than 18% in FY2005. The current account went from a 
surplus of 1.9% of GDP in FY2004 to a deficit of 1.4% of GDP in FY2005. 
 
4.  The  Government  has  embarked  on  a  major  decentralization  effort,  together  with 
nationwide reforms in public financing and management and a poverty reduction strategy. 
Strong economic growth in the last few years and a substantial increase in poverty-related 
public expenditure over the past 5 years have had a positive impact on poverty. There are 
encouraging trends in the achievement of the expenditure targets set in the Poverty Reduction

FY2002.  
 
5.  Between 2001 and 2003, unemployment decreased from 8.3% to 7.7% in Pakistan but 
increased from 7.8% to 8.2% in Balochistan.3 According to the Labor Force Survey (LFS)

III.  THE SOCIAL SERVICES SECTORS 
 A.  Sector Description and Performance 
1.  Overview 
7.  In Pakistan, Balochistan has the highest percentage of the highly deprived, in both 
income and human poverty terms: 88% of its people live in highly deprived districts (see 
Supplementary Appendix C).5 Human development indicators in Balochistan are the weakest 
among the four provinces of Pakistan and improvements will need concerted efforts over the 
long term (Appendix 3). To expedite human development and reduce income poverty, the 
government of Balochistan has formulated the Balochistan Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper 
(BPRSP) (2003),6 whose key pillars are engendering growth, managing scarce water resources, 
reforming governance, improving human development, and addressing vulnerability to shocks.  
2.  Poverty and Social Development 
8.  Balochistan has a predominantly poor rural population, which is thinly distributed over 
vast and difficult terrain. The province has 44.0% (350,000 square kilometers) of Pakistan’s land 
mass but only 5.0% of the population. Poverty in Balochistan is a consequence of several 
factors, including geography and low human capital. Inequality, though pervasive (Gini index: 
20), is less than in Pakistan as a whole (Gini index: 27) in 2001. Though poverty in Balochistan 
is more “shared” poverty, income-based inequities in human development must be addressed. 
The poor are recovering from the devastating drought that plagued the province for the last 5 
years.  The  groundwater  is  rapidly  being  depleted.  Only  6%  of  the  land  is  cultivable  and 
productivity  is  low  because  of  the  arid  conditions.  The  ethnic  diversity  and  predominantly 
patriarchal social structures are a traditional challenge to human development and gender 
equity.  
 
9.  Addressing human development needs in Balochistan is made more costly and difficult 
by the spatial distribution of household poverty, the basic infrastructure, ethnic diversity, gender 
imbalances, generational distribution of poverty, fiscal framework and fiscal traps (including the 
public investment needed to reduce poverty, and  the debt overhang), physical geography 
(including  transport  conditions  and  population  densities),  agronomic  conditions,  disease 
ecology, governance patterns and failure, cultural barriers, and geopolitics. These factors,7 
which are absent in traditional economic analysis,  must be carefully considered when planning 
development assistance for Balochistan.  
 
10.  Gender and Development. Balochistan’s social sector indicators underscore the high 
degree of gender inequality: in primary school, for example, the net primary enrollment rate is 
28% for boys but only 20% for girls. Women’s inferior status is perpetuated by their curtailed 
mobility, discriminatory tribal and cultural practices, women’s limited voice in critical household 
decisions,  and  political  marginalization.  The  gender  reform  agenda  of  the  government  is

3.  Devolution to Local Governments 
11.  Centralized  planning  and  management  of  social  services  has  created  indisciplined, 
unionized,  and  absentee  government  providers;  a  lack  of  focus  on  clients’  needs;  central 
bureaucracies overwhelmed by transfers and service litigations; and communities indifferent to 
social service delivery. As a result, public social services have become less effective and 
efficient and their quality has declined, even as they have become more inaccessible, especially 
to the poor and people living in remote areas. The Balochistan Local Government Ordinance 
(BLGO)  2001,  as  amended  from  time  to  time,  most  recently  in  June  2005,  provides  an 
institutional framework that empowers district governments, tehsil (sub-district administrative 
unit) municipal administrations (TMAs), and union administrations to manage and administer the 
education,  health,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  sectors  with  the  help  of  local 
communities. The devolution of social service management to local governments presents an 
opportunity  to  improve  service  delivery.  The  transition  from  provincial  to  local  government 
delivery involves many institutional, capacity, legal, and financial challenges, which must be 
addressed though policy reforms and TA to prepare the provincial line departments and local 
governments for their changed roles and responsibilities. The government of Balochistan has 
been addressing these transition issues with Asian Development Bank (ADB) support through 
the DSP and BRMP. Further policy reforms and assistance are needed to consolidate ongoing 
reforms and implement the next phase of reforms, improve the capacity of managers and 
providers, and encourage the private sector and ordinary citizens to participate in social service 
delivery (Supplementary Appendix D).  
4.  Social Sector Financing 
12.  Balochistan has limited room to increase its social sector expenditures partly because of 
its high debt-service burden. Currently, social sector expenditures mostly go to salaries, while 
non-salary  expenditures  are  well  below  the  global  norms  for  the  efficient  and  effective 
functioning  of  the  social  sectors.  BLGO  2001  made  the  district  governments  primarily 
responsible  for  education,  health,  and  WSS,  among  others.  However,  only  salary-related 
budgets have been devolved to the local governments; the province has retained most of the 
non-salary and development expenditures for the devolved social services. Understandably, the 
development effectiveness of the local governments has therefore been reduced (Appendix 2). 
5.  Millennium Development Goals 
13.  Net primary enrollment rates (goal 2) for both boys (28%) and girls (20%) are very low 
and improving slowly. Gender disparity in school education (goal 3) is decreasing, but is still a 
long way from the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Substantial investments will have to 
be made to achieve the MDG related to child health (goal 4). Maternal health indicators (goal 5) 
are low: only 26% of pregnant women have prenatal care, and only 21% are delivered by skilled 
birth  attendants.  Malaria  and  tuberculosis  are  major  problems,  and  the  human 
immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) requires determined 
efforts  to  contain  (goal  6).  Goal  7,  relating  to  access  to  drinking  water  and  sanitation,  is 
achievable but will need significant investments to improve access and infrastructure (Appendix 
4).

4       
 
6.  Education 
14.  Though  the  government  of  Balochistan  has  assigned  priority  to  female  and  rural 
education, gender and regional disparities remain, and much more needs to be done to meet 
the Education for All (EFA) and Education Sector Reform (ESR) targets and the MDGs. The 
literacy rate for those 10 years and above is 28%, compared with the national average of 
48%.The rural literacy rate (23%) is significantly lower than the urban rate (54%), and literacy 
among rural females (10%) is only one-third of rural males (37%) (Supplementary Appendix E).  
 
15.  Long walking distances, lack of basic amenities, and teacher absenteeism are some of 
the main factors, together with poor-quality teaching and learning materials, that are responsible 
for  low  enrollment.  Income-based  inequities  are  a  leading  cause  of  low  access  to  school 
education. While the enrollment ratio between boys and girls in Pakistan is 1.5:1, in the lowest 
income quartile it is 1.9:1, and in the lowest quartile in Balochistan it is 6.3:1. As income falls, 
parents’ willingness and resolve to educate daughters falls faster, more so in Balochistan.8 The 
continuation rate from primary to middle school is about 23%, and from middle to high school 
about 39%. A significant discrepancy in number between primary and middle schools forces 
high dropout rates after primary school. 
 
16.  The government school network comprises 11,417 schools, with a reported enrollment 
of  813,763,  including  590  “mosque”  schools  with  20,611  students.  There  are  numerous 
shelterless schools, and even where buildings are available, these are in disrepair and lack 
basic amenities like drinking water, latrines, and electricity. The shortage of female teachers is 
reflected in the student-teacher ratios: 1:10 in boys’ schools and 1:17 in girls’ schools at the 
primary level, and 1:16 in boys’ schools and 1:25 in girls’ schools in high school. During a 
survey in rural Balochistan, 25% of the schools surveyed were not holding classes because of 
teacher absenteeism. The same survey showed that even in those schools that were holding 
classes only 85% of the teachers were present.9 The disruption of teaching is acute, as most of 
the schools are either single- or two-teacher schools.  
 
17.  In  the  urban  areas,  the  private  sector—both  for-profit  and  not-for-profit  educational 
institutions—is supporting the public sector in improving access to education. The Balochistan 
Education Foundation was established to promote and finance the development of education in 
the province, but the participation of the private sector in education is generally more limited 
than in other parts of Pakistan.10 Given the sparse distribution of private institutions in most 
deprived  parts  of  Balochistan,  and  the  limited  interest  of  the  private  sector  in  providing 
education to the poor, the public school infrastructure must be strengthened to give better 
access to the rural poor and girls.11 
7.  Health 
18.  The National Health Policy 2001 gives priority to primary and secondary health care. The 
Interim  Population  Sector  Perspective  Plan  2012  (2004)  looked  forward  to  reducing  the 
population growth rate to 1.9% by 2004. The Balochistan Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper 
(BPRSP) 2003 highlights strategies in line with national population policies. Since the passage 
of BLGO 2001, major public health functions have been devolved to district governments.

19.  Balochistan province must overcome major challenges to achieve the MDGs related to 
infant and maternal health. Around 158 out of every 1,000 children born do not reach their fifth

also found to be very low (20% overall, with urban-rural variation of 44% and 15%, respectively). 
Only  14%  of  married  women  use  modern  contraceptives  (15%,  if  all  other  contraceptive 
methods are considered). The fertility rate for the province in 1998, according to the census that 
year, was 5.4. 
 
20.  HIV/AIDS and Infectious Diseases. Malaria and tuberculosis pose serious threats to 
the health of the poor in Balochistan. Tuberculosis incidence is 177 per 100,000 population. 
There is a need to expand and strengthen directly observed therapy (DOTS) to deal effectively 
with the tuberculosis problem in the province. The annual parasite incidence of 6.56 for malaria 
in  Balochistan  is  almost  30  times  the  parasite  incidence  for  the  whole  country.  Effective 
measures to control the malaria vector and treat malaria cases are important to improve health 
and reduce anemia and other morbidities in women and children. The HIV/AIDS epidemic is 
mainly concentrated among injecting drug users in the province. A quick and concerted effort is 
required to control the spread of HIV/AIDS. HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis are discussed 
in detail in Appendix 5. 
 
21.  The private health sector comprises mostly private clinics run by a general duty doctor 
and a paramedic/nurse or a less qualified person. Private practice after office hours is common 
among public sector doctors. There are more than 3,500 registered pharmacies, mostly in urban 
areas,  which  sell  drugs  over  the  counter  with  limited  prescribing.  The  Balochistan  Health 
Foundation has, until September 2004, provided financial assistance to 17 projects. 
8.  Water Supply and Sanitation 
22.  Nearly one half of the population of Balochistan relies on unprotected wells, ponds, 
canals, or streams for their drinking water needs. In rural areas, where the burden of fetching 
water largely falls on women and girls, only 39% of households have access to improved water 
sources within a 2-kilometer distance or a half-hour walk from their homes.13 Over-extraction of 
groundwater resulting from both population pressures and electricity subsidies for agricultural 
tube wells (refer to Supplementary Appendix G for details) has led to rapid depletion of the 
water table. Drinking water is often polluted and distributed without treatment. Furthermore,

23.  Access to adequate sanitation varies considerably among the districts in the province:  
in only five districts is sanitation accessible to more than 51% of the population; in nine districts

sanitation coverage is only 4–25%. Access to sewage disposal infrastructure is largely absent.  
In most districts, less than 3% of the population has access to wastewater disposal facilities.  
Balochistan  has  no  wastewater  treatment  facilities.  In  urban  areas,  household  sewage  is

litters the landscape, particularly in urban areas and along main roads. Apart from Quetta, 
Gwadar, and Kila Abdullah towns, solid waste collection, transportation, and disposal coverage

and land reclamation, or thrown into drains and watercourses. 
 
24.  BLGO 2001 also turned over responsibility for water supply, sanitation, and solid waste 
collection to local governments. The public health engineering (PHE) department has been 
devolved to the district governments, while solid waste management (in both rural and urban 
areas of the tehsil) is now the responsibility of TMAs. The district governments, with funds from 
the provincial department, are responsible for the operation and maintenance (O&M) of all water 
supply schemes built before 1992.  
 
25.  After 1992, the 962 schemes developed by the PHE department were handed over to 
the  communities  for  O&M.  The  communities  report  difficulties  in  meeting  operation  costs, 
because of very high electricity bills and bills with varying tariff structures. In Quetta, WSS is the 
responsibility  of  the  Quetta  Water  and  Sanitation  Authority,  while  solid  waste  collection, 
transportation, and disposal are undertaken by the municipal administrations of Chiltan and 
Zarghoon towns. No TMA has proper facilities for the collection and sanitary disposal of hospital 
waste. The water agencies and municipal bodies traditionally charged with managing water 
supply, wastewater, and solid waste suffer from financial weaknesses that prevent them from 
generating  capital  to  rehabilitate,  improve,  and  expand  infrastructure  and  facilities.  Private 
sector operators have developed tube wells on private land, particularly in Quetta, for the 
purpose of selling water to water vendors. The private sector participates in the transportation of 
solid waste and in recycling schemes, which involve the purchase of materials such as paper, 
glass, and iron produced and segregated by households. Several nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs)  in  Balochistan  are  supporting  the  development  of  small  community-driven  WSS 
schemes. NGOs are also active in promoting hygiene and sanitation and the construction of 
household toilets, both in urban and rural areas. 
B.  Issues, Opportunities, and Lessons 
1.  Issues and Opportunities 
26.  The  government  of  Balochistan  is  committed  to  alleviating  poverty  and  gender 
imbalance in a holistic manner, through such means as public service delivery. The local 
government system put in place by BLGO 2001 offers major opportunities for reforms and a 
level of political representation that is closer to and more dependent on public interests. The 
basis for the devolution of social service delivery is a clearer definition of intergovernmental 
functions. Actual delivery responsibility is devolved to local governments with revenue-matching 
expenditure assignments and associated control over establishment and service delivery outfits. 
The  province  will  have  key  policy,  financing,  standard-setting,  mentoring/technical,  legality 
control, and evaluation functions.

7
 
27.  It is evident that to make public service delivery more efficient, equitable, effective, and 
sustainable,  serious  problems  in  the  economic,  social,  legal,  and  political  aspects  of 
governance,  participation,  and  financing  must  be  addressed.  ADB  and  other  development 
partners support both BPRSP and the strengthening of the financial framework through better 
budget planning and execution and smoother intergovernmental flows, to make decentralization 
work. The BRMP provides major policy reforms to strengthen devolution and improve public 
service  delivery.  The  recently  notified  Balochistan  Performance  Grant  Rules  (BPGR)  2005 
provide a flexible mechanism for providing conditional transfers to local governments to make 
pro-poor service delivery more responsive to local needs, within the policy priorities of the 
province. 
 
28.  In  Balochistan,  the  following  opportunities  can  be  tapped  to  improve  social  service 
delivery: (i) giving provincial line departments an effective role in policy making and standard 
setting while leaving the management and control of devolved subjects to local governments; 
(ii) assigning responsibilities to local governments by passing supporting rules to transfer power 
of appointing and transferring staff; approve and sanction development schemes; and enforce 
efficiency and discipline rules; and (iii) restructuring vertical programs and the public sector 
development program to bring them in line with the mandate of BLGO 2001. ADB’s support for 
Balochistan  is  growing  (Supplementary  Appendix  H)  and  is  significant  given  the  immense 
human development challenges in Balochistan and the limited donor presence (Appendix 6). 
 
29.  Through appropriate policy reforms and capacity building, the following issues can be 
addressed more effectively by provincial and local governments: accountability of providers; 
corruption  and  misconduct;  use  of  staff  resources;  staff  absenteeism;  performance-based 
incentives; female staff deployment; sector strategic frameworks and action plans and sector 
planning capacity in the local governments; constraints posed by the dispersed population; the 
failure of the “one-size-fits-all” formula in the provision and location of facilities; and the absence 
of priorities or thresholds for various types and levels of service. 
 
30.  Predictable  financing  for  devolved  social  sectors,  including  development  budgets 
consistent with BLGO 2001 and expenditure assignments from the provincial budget, is critical. 
Other issues related to financial management are: (i) absence of reliable, timely, and complete 
information on provincial and district government transactions; (ii) poor financial controls at all 
levels; (iii) inadequate budgetary and financial discipline; (iv) delays in audits; (v) lack of public 
access to financial statements; (vi) inadequate expenditure prioritization; and (vii) absence of 
expenditure yardsticks for the allocation of non-salary expenditures. 
 
31.  The  centralization  of  decision  making  in  the  province  leaves  little  room  for  citizen 
participation in government functioning at the local level. There is limited transparency, little 
public participation at the local level, and no direct accountability to stakeholders since (i) very 
few documents are available to the public; (ii) there are no reports on the performance of the 
provincial or local governments; (iii) there are no mechanisms for the redressal of grievances; 
and (iv) the partnerships between government and civil society or the private sector remain 
limited. 
 
32.  To increase accountability, the BLGO emphasizes the role of the community, citizen 
community boards (CCBs), public-private partnerships, and the private sector in expanding 
social services, and provides for citizen oversight in the social sectors. This links well with the 
realities on the ground, where communities and the private sector (including NGOs) have been 
assisting in the expansion of social sector service delivery. However, it does require a change of 
mind-set. Devolution provides a unique opportunity to make this happen.

8       
 
2.  Lessons Identified 
33.  Important  lessons  learned  from  past  donor  support  and  ADB’s  own  experiences  in 
general and devolved social services programs in Sindh and Punjab have been incorporated in 
the program design. The experiences of the Social Action Program (SAP) and the lessons 
learned are given in Supplementary Appendix I. The decade-long SAP did not lead to tangible 
improvements in the delivery of basic social services. The breakdown of governance, where the 
poor were marginalized by limited or no access to public facilities, characterized the SAP period. 
Government facilities remained weak, with many facilities cited not functioning because of lack 
of staff, especially teachers and health workers, despite SAP investments.  
 
34.  The  DSSPs  of  Sindh,  Punjab,  and  Balochistan  are  compared  in  Supplementary 
Appendix J. Integration with other ADB programs, including DSP and BRMP, is expected to 
generate  synergy  for  the  success  of  BDSSP  by  ensuring  better  risk  mitigation  measures, 
building on the enabling environment created by these programs, and prioritizing issues for 
policy  dialogue.  BRMP  supported  the  notification  of  BPGR  2005,  which  will  facilitate  the 
implementation of performance grants in BDSSP. Advance actions to ensure timely TA have 
emerged as critical to program success. For policy dialogue and sustained reforms, a robust 
framework  for  devolved  social  services  was  deemed  necessary.  Clear  policies  arrived  at 
through rigorous policy dialogue were considered essential, as were clear agreements with 
specific, achievable, measurable, realistic, and timely policy action indicators. It was also felt 
that the strong incentives for the province had to be part of the program design.  
 
35.  There is an urgent need to fix social service delivery by also addressing the underlying 
governance issues. The traditional project emphasis on specific project components has limited 
impact on governance and institutional issues. Ongoing investments in public social services 
must  be  improved  through  governance  and  institutional  reforms—mainly  through  policy 
reforms—while increasing the scope for effective and well-targeted investments in public social 
sectors. The BDSSP design will include both policy reforms and additional investments in 
devolved social services through performance grants; the investments must be targeted and 
capable of being tracked and measured. However, reform is a long-term endeavor, and will 
require long-term support from external donor partners, including ADB. The policy and program 
responses must build on past successful approaches, adapted to a devolved setting. Targeting 
social sector investments to reach the poor, in areas of maximum impact on poverty reduction, 
is critical. BDSSP proposes social sector investments through performance grants in areas with 
the  highest  impact  on  poverty  reduction,  and  includes  public  expenditure  tracking  and 
quantitative service delivery surveys to assess the quality of targeting and the development 
impact of the program. The problem-tree analysis and options are discussed in Supplementary 
Appendix K.

access to affordable, efficient, effective, and good-quality education, health, and WSS in the

B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
1.  Policy Framework 
37.  The  conceptual  framework  for  the  policy  reforms  is  adapted  from  the  framework 
proposed in ADB, World Bank, and Department for International Development (DFID) report on 
devolution in Pakistan.15 The role of the private sector in the delivery of social services—both 
publicly and privately financed—has been increasing in importance (Supplementary Appendix 
L); hence, strengthening the role of the private sector in a devolved setting is included in the 
framework as a policy reform outcome. Figure 1 summarizes the conceptual framework and the 
four major policy reform areas and outcomes. The government of Balochistan has expressed its 
commitment to the reforms and to increased social sector spending (Appendix 7). The policy 
reform  outcomes,  policy  reform  areas,  and  agreed  actions  are  given  in  the  policy  matrix 
(Appendix 8). The four major policy reform areas are described below. 
2.  Policy Reform Outcomes 
38.  The  program  has  four  principal  policy  areas:  (i)  provincial  efficiency  incentives; 
(ii) managerial power; (iii) citizens’ voice and empowerment; and (iv) private sector engagement. 
 
39.  Provincial Efficiency Incentives. These incentives strengthen the relationship between 
provincial and local governments so that social service delivery is improved through efficiency 
gains including budgetary certainties, greater autonomy in budget preparation, and incentives 
for improved fiscal management by local governments.  
 
40.  Managerial  Power.  This  aims  to  strengthen  the  relationship  between  the  district 
governments and the providers of social services. The local governments engage with service 
delivery  providers  through  managerial  power,  which  reflects  their  ability  to  require  service 
providers to follow particular standards of behavior and service. The reforms in this area would 
deal, among others, with posting and transfers, authority of district governments over senior 
staff, external oversight, and adequate deployment of staff.

3.  Policy Reform Areas 
a.  Provincial Efficiency Incentives 
43.  Policy Reform Area (PRA) 1.1: Budget Certainty for Social Sectors. One of the 
objectives of BDSSP is to improve the availability and certainty of funding to local governments 
for  their  social  sectors.  The  performance  grant  mechanism  under  BPGR  2005  is  to  be 
operationalized.  A  TA  loan  will  support  a  study  on  the  integration  of  the  present  vertical 
programs in social sectors that are funded or supported by the federal Government, to allow the 
transfer of funds to local governments. The study is expected to lead to agreed actions and, if 
necessary, those will be taken up with the Government of Pakistan. Further, the scope of 
performance grants to local governments would be enlarged to include special programs, block 
grants, and umbrella projects/programs in the devolved social sectors. 
 
44.  PRA  1.2:  Autonomy  in  Budget  Preparation  and  Administrative  Actions.  
The mandate of the local governments to govern and to plan, prioritize, implement, manage, 
and deliver devolved social services requires them to be thus empowered under the rules and 
procedures.  Local  governments  must  have  powers  to  approve  and  sanction  schemes.  In 
addition, the responsibilities of provincial departments for the devolved social sectors would 
need to be redesigned to conform to their new role under the provincial-local relationships 
necessitated by BLGO 2001. BDSSP, through a TA loan, will support a study on the role and 
responsibilities of the provincial departments (education, health, public health engineering), 
considering the need to strengthen their policy formulation, standard setting, and technical 
support  and  capacity  building  of  local  governments,  and  will  assist  in  implementing  its 
recommendations. 
 
45.  PRA 1.3: Improved Quality of Social Services. This is an area of central concern, and 
BDSSP  would  support  measures  taken  by  the  government  of  Balochistan  to  provide  and 
strengthen the framework for quality improvements at the local level. These measures would 
include (i) sector strategy and action plans, (ii) expenditure allocation yardsticks, (iii) sector-
specific actions such as introducing a package of essential services in the health sector, and 
(iv) institutional support to build the capacity of sector managers and service providers by 
strengthening the planning cell in the provincial health department, creating a provincial corps of 
trainers  to  prepare  master  trainers  at  the  district  level  for  in-service  teacher  training, 
strengthening the Institute of Public Health in Quetta and the paramedical and nursing training 
schools outside Quetta, and other means. 
b.  Managerial Power 
46.  PRA  2.1:  Authority  to  District  Governments  to  Appoint  and  Transfer  Staff. 
Personnel management is controlled by the government of Balochistan, which continues to 
exercise  administrative  powers  over  appointments  and  transfers.  District  government  staff 
continues to have direct links with their administrative departments at the cost of horizontal 
linkages, coordination, harmony, discipline, and accountability. This situation seriously hampers 
the ability and performance of local governments. BDSSP policy reform therefore involves 
giving local governments authority to appoint and transfer staff and to enforce efficiency and 
discipline rules in the education, health, and public health engineering departments. 
 
47.  PRA 2.2: Adequate Deployment of Staff. To ensure adequately staffed facilities and to 
provide greater accountability at the community level, BDSSP would support the development of 
a system of contract appointments for specific facilities in the education and health sectors. The 
appointments, which may involve hiring retired government servants on contract, cannot be 
regularized.

48.  PRA  2.3:  Improved  Capacities  of  District  Managers  and  Service  Providers.  
Management support systems, such as database and management information systems (MIS), 
will be strengthened in the education and health sectors, particularly at the local government 
level, and will be developed for the WSS sector. An ongoing health MIS initiative will be 
assessed to identify gaps and areas for further support. BDSSP will provide TA for the required 
systems strengthening. Further, the BDSSP TA will support the development of a system of 
performance-linked incentives for sector managers and service delivery staff, and performance 
grants will fund pilot implementation.  
 
49.  Along with the strengthening of management support through the timely availability of 
improved data, sector managers at the district level will become better able to prepare medium-
term and annual work programs and budgets, and undertake financial management monitoring, 
reporting, and audit. BDSSP will provide TA to develop training courses and to conduct training 
at the district level. The quality of social services depends on the capacity of the front-end 
service  providers,  especially  in  the  case  of  schoolteachers  and  primary  health  care  staff. 
BDSSP will support the training of master trainers at district headquarters by the provincial 
corps of trainers developed under the TA. These master trainers will provide in-service training 
at various locations within the district to schoolteachers, high-school head teachers in school 
management, and school supervisors. In the health sector, in-service training according to the 
training plan developed under the TA will be supported at the district level. 
c.  Citizens’ Voice and Empowerment 
50.  PRA  3.1:  Grievance  Redressal  Mechanisms.  BDSSP  will  provide  TA  support  to 
develop and institute grievance redressal mechanisms in the provincial and local governments, 
particularly  at  the  service  delivery  level.  Support  will  be  provided  to  operationalize  the 
mechanisms  envisaged  under  BLGO  2001,  including  complaint  cells.  The  TA  will  help 
strengthen local government monitoring committees. 
 
51.  PRA  3.2:  Community  Management  of  Facilities.  The  creation  of  CCBs  to  foster 
community participation in local government and service delivery are envisaged in BLGO 2001, 
and local governments are obliged to provide 25% of their development funds to support the 
CCBs.  BDSSP  will  establish  linkages  with  programs  supporting  the  promotion  and 
strengthening of CCBs. It will provide a TA loan for the drafting of a communication strategy to 
promote  and  strengthen  community  involvement  in  the  management  of  facilities,  and  will 
support the implementation of the strategy. In the education sector, parent-teacher school 
management committees (PTSMCs) have been formed in many schools, and their formation 
and  strengthening  is  being  promoted  under  the  ongoing  Environmental  Sector  Reform 
Assistance (ESRA) program funded by the United States Agency for International Development 
(USAID).  BDSSP  will  develop  linkages  in  the  districts  where  the  ESRA  program  is  being 
implemented, and support the process in all other districts where the program is not being 
implemented. BDSSP will develop and introduce hospital management boards in district and 50-
bed hospitals on a pilot basis and will later expand this support to include all district and 50-bed 
hospitals. 
 
52.  PRA  3.3:  Civil  Society  Monitoring  of  Social  Service  Delivery,  and  Citizen 
Oversight. Citizens’ voice and community empowerment are important features of the local 
government system under BLGO 2001, particularly in the delivery of social services. However, 
citizens’ monitoring of elected public representatives, as provided under BLGO 2001, is not yet 
well established. BDSSP will therefore facilitate and support the operationalization of citizen 
oversight and monitoring programs. First, the BDSSP TA will prepare a program of civil society

13
monitoring,  look  at  the  various  mechanisms  for  local  government  monitoring  and  citizen 
oversight, and implement a system of citizen report cards on a pilot basis in the city district of 
Quetta. The TA will, in addition, support the provincial finance department in introducing public 
expenditure tracking surveys, and the provincial bureau of statistics in introducing quantitative 
service delivery surveys and validating the results. The provincial and district governments will 
be required to make available to the public all reports on the surveys and the third-party 
assessment and validation. 
d.  Private Sector Engagement 
53.  PRA 4.1: Private Sector Participation. BDSSP will provide support under the TA loan 
for a comprehensive review of policy options for PPP and PSP, and prepare a strategy and plan 
for the consideration and approval of the government of Balochistan. The TA will examine 
alternative options for the delivery of health services in sparsely populated areas and implement 
selected options on a pilot basis. In the education sector, the TA will support the development of 
an  action  plan  for  engaging  the  private  sector  in  the  development  of  innovative  teaching 
materials.  
 
54.  PRA 4.2: Self-Regulation by the Private Sector. To address the issue of the quality of 
private sector services, TA support will be made available for the development of a strategy for 
self-regulation by the private sector in education and health, and it’s the implementation of the 
strategy  after  it  is  approved.  BDSSP,  through  performance  grants,  will  support  the 
implementation by the local governments of the approved strategy and plan for PSP and PPP 
prepared  under  the  TA.  Performance  grants  will  also  be  provided  to  support  the  wider 
implementation of successful initiatives implemented on a pilot basis under the TA. 
4.  Performance Grants 
55.  Performance  grants  to  eligible  district  governments  and  TMAs  will  be  allocated 
according to the agreed formula under the provincial finance commission (PFC) award for the 
distribution  of  resources  between  districts  and  eligible  TMAs.  The  administration  of  the 
performance grants will follow the implementation arrangements under BPGR 2005, as already 
agreed under BRMP. The performance grants will support district governments and eligible 
TMAs in accelerating progress toward the MDGs in education, health, and WSS, within the 
broad policy reform framework agreed with the government of Balochistan. The performance 
grants will be funded from two sources: a $65 million ADF loan and a $5 million ADF grant. 
These grants will be restricted to the education, health, and water supply and sanitation sectors. 
The district governments and the TMAs will have flexibility to allocate funds from the $65 million 
ADF loan among these three sectors according to local needs as long as each sector receives 
at least 20% of the allocations. This will enable the local governments to adopt more effective, 
demand-driven, and participatory planning to identify gaps and rationalize and develop services 
with full ownership of the interventions decided by them. However, to ensure balanced progress 
in an accelerated manner toward the MDGs and to enable implementation of the policy reforms, 
components targeting priority investments in education, health, and WSS within the policy 
reform framework have been defined (Appendix 9). A $5 million ADF grant for HIV/AIDS and 
infectious diseases will support a specific sub-component of the health sector (sub-component 
07B in Appendix 9) to prevent HIV/AIDS and to prevent and treat malaria, tuberculosis, and 
other infectious diseases.  
C.  Important Features 
56.  BDSSP is the first ADB-supported program loan for the social sectors in Balochistan. 
Given past experiences, the importance of supporting governance reforms in the social sectors 
cannot  be  underestimated.  This  aspect  assumes  greater  significance  in  the  context  of

14      
 
devolution and the local government structures introduced under BLGO 2001. BDSSP can 
therefore be seen as primarily a governance program for the devolved social sectors that aims 
to build local government responsibility, accountability, and capacity while at the same time 
improving  intergovernmental  frameworks  to  enable  local  governments  to  exercise  their 
mandates under BLGO 2001. Thus, local governments would be able to effectively plan and 
efficiently implement and manage social services according to their own needs and priorities. 
 
57.  BDSSP  can  be  seen  as  phase  three  of  ongoing  support  to  the  government  of 
Balochistan.  The  DSP,  in  the  first  phase,  provided  support  for  the  strengthening  of  local 
governments, and laid out the institutional context. BRMP, in the second phase, supported and 
strengthened resource management, and initiated the strengthening of social sector delivery. 
BDSSP will continue the reforms of DSP and BRMP, and create synergistic linkages with the 
earlier  reforms.  BDSSP  policy  reforms  have  been  designed  through  an  iterative  process 
involving the provincial government, local governments, civil society, service providers, and 
clients.  The  performance  grants  were  designed  with  the  full  participation  of  the  local 
governments at all levels: district, tehsil, and unions. Participatory meetings at the district and 
TMA levels were attended by elected representatives, sector managers of the education, health, 
and WSS sectors, and front-end service providers. Further dialogues were held at the provincial 
level  with  the  participation  of  provincial  officials,  civil  society,  sector  NGOs,  and  local 
government functionaries.  
 
58.  BDSSP has special provisions for promoting gender equity and the participation of the 
poor,  the  vulnerable  and  marginalized  groups.  Particular  attention  has  been  focused  on 
improving access to education for girls and to providing and expanding reproductive health 
facilities. The expansion of the pool of female teachers, female health service providers (LHVs, 
community midwives, paramedics) supported by the program is an integral part of the design 
strategy. Further, the improvement of water supply and the focus on sanitation at the household 
and community level will be of benefit to women by reducing the drudgery associated with water 
collection and maintaining hygiene. BDSSP has built-in synergies in its TA component and also 
provides for linkages with ongoing initiatives aimed at supporting devolution and the local 
government system.  
 
D.  ADF IX Grant for HIV/AIDS and Infectious Diseases Control 
59.  Combating high morbidity and mortality due to malaria and tuberculosis, preventing the 
spread of HIV/AIDS in high-risk groups, and raising general awareness of HIV/AIDS among the 
largely  illiterate  population  of  Balochistan  will  be  challenging  and  resource-intensive.  The 
various aspects of the challenge are described in Appendix 5, while the serious resource 
constraints that hamper the measures against HIV/AIDS and other infectious diseases are given 
in  Appendix  2.  The  $5  million  HIV/AIDS  and  infectious  diseases  grant  from  ADB’s  ADF 
resources will finance specific components of health sector performance grants that will have a 
high impact on the prevention of HIV/AIDS, and on the prevention and treatment of malaria and 
tuberculosis.  As  described  in  Appendix  9,  this  grant  will  finance  specific  components  to 
(i) increase awareness  of  HIV/AIDS  and  measures  to  control  its  spread;  (ii)  improve  case 
detection of tuberculosis and increase access to treatment, mainly through directly observed 
therapy;  (iii)  control  malaria  vectors,  and  detect  and  treat  malaria  cases;  and  (iv)  control 
childhood infectious diseases by increasing access to the expanded program on immunization. 
The  grant  outputs  and  outcomes  will  be  carefully  monitored  through  the  routine  reporting 
mechanisms  of  the  program  loan  and  through  public  expenditure  tracking  surveys  and 
quantitative service delivery surveys.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Program Benefits 
92.  Institutionalized Planning. Social sector planning has so far been largely ad hoc, 
nonparticipatory, and non-transparent. The social sector functionaries assigned to the districts 
have no planning and budgeting capacity in the past. Among the BDSSP policy reforms are 
empowering local government functionaries and providing TA support in developing strategic 
plans, promoting public-private partnerships, developing self-regulation by the private sector at 
the provincial level, and building the capacity of social sector managers in local governments to 
institutionalize district planning and programming and develop management capacity. BDSSP 
will work closely with BRMP and establish synergy with other ongoing reform programs like DSP 
and the USAID-funded ESRA program. 
 
93.  Performance  Grants.  BDSSP  will  increase  funding  for  the  social  services  through 
performance grant transfers under the BPGR 2005 promulgated by government of Balochistan. 
The performance grants are designed to enable local governments to provide a flexible, needs-
based response to local conditions, adopt an effective demand-driven and participatory planning 
process to identify service gaps, and rationalize and develop services with full ownership of the 
interventions decided by them. At the same time, the grants and sub-grants target priority 
investments in the social sectors in accordance with the provincial policy frameworks to ensure 
balanced progress in an accelerated manner toward the MDGs and the BDSSP policy reforms. 
The TA will assist in developing the capacity of local governments to effectively plan, implement, 
and manage their development activities. 
 
94.  Pro-poor  Services.  BDSSP  interventions  especially  target  the  needs  of  the  most 
vulnerable,  including  women  and  the  poor.  The  provision  of  merit  scholarships  and  basic 
amenities in girls’ schools will improve access to education for girls. Similarly, trained lady 
health volunteers and female doctors in health-care facilities would provide poor women with 
better maternal health care. Performance grant funding to local governments for basic social 
services and the introduction of a package of minimum essential services will especially benefit 
the poor and vulnerable.  
 
95.  Public-Private Partnerships and Community Involvement. The BDSSP TA will help 
the government of Balochistan develop a strategy and action plan to promote public-private

23
partnerships  in  social  service  delivery;  innovate  improvements  in  the  quality,  access,  and 
delivery of social services; and develop and implement a self-regulatory mechanism for the 
private sector. Performance grants to local governments will support the implementation of the 
strategy developed under the TA and promote community and private sector initiatives in the 
delivery of services to hard-to-reach, sparsely populated areas.  
B.  Impacts 
96.  Social Impact. BDSSP will further Balochistan’s progress toward the MDGs and the 
social sector targets defined in the BPRSP. Initiatives aimed at improving access to education 
would, in the long run, help increase net enrollment in and encourage completion of primary 
school, and help reduce the gender gap in enrollment and completion rates. Similarly, better 
access to health services would help reduce the number of underweight children, and lower 
child mortality and maternal mortality rates. The availability of basic sanitation facilities and the 
provision  of  safe  drinking  water  would  improve  living  conditions,  reduce  the  incidence  of 
disease, and ultimately assist in raising the productivity of the population (Appendix 13).  
 
97.  Gender  Impact.  BDSSP  can  improve  the  quality  of  women’s  lives  and  lay  the 
groundwork  for  greater  autonomy  for  women  in  both  the  public  and  private  spheres. 
Interventions targeting girls will accelerate progress toward increased enrollment and continued 
education for girls at all levels of schooling. An increase in the number of women with secondary 
education  would  also  advance  their  economic  independence  and  empowerment,  and  also 
reduce infant mortality. Increasing the capacity of female elected representatives would enable 
them to be actively involved and have their voice heard in the management and monitoring of 
public service facilities. In general, women’s participation in public affairs would be strengthened 
(Supplementary Appendix N).  
 
98.  Institutional Impact. BDSSP will strengthen the local government system. Its policy 
reforms will assist the government of Balochistan in defining the new role of provincial social 
sector departments under the changed relationships prescribed in BLGO 2001. BDSSP will 
assist in and provide linkages with ongoing activities to support the capacity building of local 
councilors, especially women councilors, to make them better able to effectively plan, manage, 
and implement initiatives to improve service delivery. It will further institutionalize community 
and  civil  society  involvement  in  local  government  affairs,  particularly  through  strengthened 
monitoring by elected representatives and civil society, and, community involvement in the 
management of social services through CCBs, PTSMCs, hospital management boards, and 
other innovative mechanisms to institutionalize citizens’ voice and empowerment.  
 
99.  Poverty  and  Economic  Impact.  By  enabling  the  local  governments,  through 
performance grants, to spend more than they have been doing on education, health, and water 
supply and sanitation, BDSSP will help gain greater access for the poor and vulnerable to basic 
social services. BDSSP, even in a small way, will help open up employment and income 
opportunities and create human and physical assets particularly in the remote and sparsely 
populated areas, through local recruitment support to local private service providers in setting 
up  service  delivery  outlets.  Public-private  partnerships  will  also  facilitate  the  creation  of 
productive opportunities (Supplementary Appendix O). 
 
100.  Environmental Impact. The program loan is classified as environmental category B on 
the basis of the environmental assessment of the proposed BDSSP carried out to identify 
potential environmental outcomes and measures to prevent or mitigate adverse environmental 
impacts. The environmental assessment of the four policy interventions has shown that most of 
the  policy  actions  will  have  substantial  positive  impact  on  the  environment.  Any  potential

24      
 
negative environmental impacts of increased expenditure in the water supply, sanitation, and 
health sectors are adequately addressed through the eligibility criteria for the performance 
grants and the increased capacity building for environmental management, to be supported 
under  the  associated  TA  loan.  The  environmental  assessment  summary,  including  an 
assessment  of  the  policy  actions  and  an  environmental  management  plan,  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix P. 
 
101.  Sustainability Impact. Program sustainability is a key issue. Various factors including 
program  design  strengthen  sustainability.  BDSSP  is  designed  to  support  the  provincial 
government’s own initiative mainly emanating from BLGO 2001, which devolved social services. 
BDSSP is closely integrated and builds on the enabling environment created by DSP and 
BRMP. The performance grants will be administered through the institutional framework of the 
government (BPGR 2005). The refinancing of high-interest debt with OCR funds will create 
sustainable fiscal space. The TA support to build evaluation capacities and processes will also 
help  make  the  program  interventions  more  sustainable.  Moreover,  empowered  local 
governments  and  citizens  are  expected  to  play  key  roles  in  sustaining  the  program 
interventions.  By  supporting  public  expenditure  tracking  and  quantitative  service  delivery 
surveys,  the  program  will  institutionalize  strong  monitoring  systems,  and  thus  improve 
efficiencies and sustainability in the long run. If, as anticipated, there will be less human and 
income poverty, with the help of the program, there will ultimately also be less demand for social 
sector expenditures.  
C.  Risks  
102.  Political Risks. The political situation in Balochistan tends to be difficult. The coalition 
government  has  a  wide  constituency  to  satisfy  and  therefore  faces  contending  pressures. 
Devolution is seen in some political quarters as giving up too much provincial power, so much 
so that there could be attempts to recentralize. Recent local government elections (August–
September 2005), while ushering in local government representatives with a fresh mandate, had 
a large number of uncontested seats, providing a grim reminder that the process is evolving and 
far from perfect. The issue is more a matter of perspective and appreciation of the realigned 
roles and responsibilities of provincial and local governments under BLGO 2001. The policy 
dialogue during the program design must continue during program implementation to mitigate 
the risks. BDSSP is better positioned to be involved in serious policy dialogue and mitigate 
some of the political risks. ADB has sustained policy dialogue and interaction with senior civil 
services and civil society in Balochistan over the past half-decade, starting with DSP and 
continuing with Access to Justice Program and more recently with BRMP. This medium-term 
involvement in Balochistan and well-orchestrated support at the program level will substantially 
reduce the perceived political risks. 
 
103.  Governance and Bureaucratic Risks. There is a risk that some people will resist the 
new  transparent  and  accountable  processes  and  will  be  reluctant  to  change  systems.  
To mitigate that risk, high-level support and a high-level steering committee will be important. 
Further  risk  mitigation  is  expected  through  BDSSP  policy  actions  including  special  audits, 
publicly available accounts and expenditures, and public grievance mechanisms. A major focus 
of BDSSP is improving social sector governance such that decisions become more transparent 
and objective and rent seeking is minimized. Vested interests might therefore be expected to 
delay  or  undermine  the  implementation  of  reforms.  BDSSP  includes  such  risk  mitigation 
measures  as  building  stakeholder  ownership  during  program  design  and  implementation, 
establishing  program  oversight  mechanisms  including  the  participation  of  local  government 
council  committees,  and  ensuring  synergy  with  other  reform  programs.  Strengthening

25
monitoring  systems  and  emphasizing  transparency  and  public  disclosure  would  also  help 
mitigate this risk. 
 
104.  Capacity Constraints. Fast-track devolution has brought with it a substantial agenda of 
political, administrative, and fiscal restructuring, new systems, rules, and guidelines, and the 
need to train administrators and councilors. However, the local government systems must be 
fully operationalized and the provincial departments and agencies must be geared to fully 
support  the  process.  A  major  concern  is  the  limited  financial,  managerial,  and  technical 
responsibilities that have been devolved in practice as well as the narrow capacity of local 
government functionaries. These risks will be mitigated by policy reforms to rationalize the roles 
and responsibilities of the provincial departments in the light of their changed relationship with 
the  local  governments  under  BLGO  2001,  and  by  the  local  government  capacity-building 
activities financed under the TA. 
 
105.  Fiduciary Risk. During the preparation of the BRMP, the fiduciary risk to public funds 
arising from the lack of accountability and transparency in financial management was identified 
as  a  concern.  BRMP  policy  reforms  are  helping  to  establish  reliable,  transparent,  and 
accountable financial management systems to address this fiduciary risk. In addition, specific 
financial management arrangements for the performance grants that will be funded through the 
ADF loan and grant have been agreed, including the regular audit of the performance grant 
program. The ongoing efforts to strengthen public financial management, the project-specific 
financial management arrangements, and other measures and assurances will mitigate this risk.

FISCAL STATUS AND SOCIAL SECTOR FINANCING IN BALOCHISTAN 
 
1.  Overview. The government of Balochistan requires additional financial resources to 
achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and targets set in the Balochistan Poverty 
Reduction Strategy Paper (BPRSP). The government has expressed its commitment to improve 
the provision of social services in the BPRSP, which is based on the MDGs. The estimated 
financial implications of the BPRSP were included in the medium-term budgetary framework 
(MTBF) for FY2004–FY2006, and updated in the medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) for 
FY2006–FY2008. 
 
2.  Unfortunately, budget growth has been less than the worst-case scenario in the MTBF. It 
is  also  necessary  to  accelerate  improvement  in  the  social  sectors,  to  improve  the  social 
indicators to the levels achieved in other provinces in Pakistan, and to achieve the MDGs on 
time. The government of Balochistan therefore needs a large amount of additional financial 
resources for the social sectors for the next several years. The Balochistan Devolved Social 
Services Program (BDSSP) will provide the provincial government with the additional financial 
resources  to  meet  the  resource  gap  and  finance  eligible  district  governments  through 
performance grants. 
 
3.  Resources of the Government of Balochistan. The revenue receipts of the provincial 
government are heavily dependent on transfers from the federal Government, but the recent 
increase in revenue receipts was primarily due to a gradual increase in the revenues of the 
province itself. Revenue receipts grew at an average annual rate of 10.5% between FY2002 
and FY2005, and totaled PRs30.9 billion in FY2005 (Table A2.1). The revenue receipts consist 
largely of federal transfers and grants (about 95%); provincial revenues make up about 5%. The 
federal  transfers  grew  by  an  average  1.8%  yearly  between  FY2002  and  FY2005,  while 
provincial revenues increased yearly by an average of 13.1%. The resources for development, 
on the other hand, come from four major sources: net surplus from revenue, capital, and public 
accounts, and development receipts. Development resources were PRs12.8 billion in FY2005. 
 
4.  Expenditure of the Government of Balochistan. The major revenue expenditure items 
of the government have been provincial allocable, general administration, and debt servicing. 
The revenue expenditure increased at an annual average rate of 12.9% between FY2002 and 
FY2005, and totaled PRs28.5 billion in FY2005. As a result of the administrative and financial 
devolution following the passage of Balochistan Local Government Ordinance (BLGO) 2001, 
more than two thirds of the revenue expenditure has been allocated to provincial allocable. 
General administration has been allocated 9.5–14.3%, and debt servicing 10.8–15.2%. The 
development expenditure, on the other hand, has been equal to development resources; the 
government of Balochistan has used all development resources each year. 
 
5.  Provincial  Allocable.  Since  the  passage  of  BLGO  2001,  several  functions  of  the 
provincial departments have been devolved to the local governments. As a result, a large 
portion of the revenue expenditure was allocated to provincial allocable, most of which went to 
local governments as grants. In the budget for FY2002, out of the total current expenditure of 
PRs19.8 billion, PRs6.7 billion (33.8%) was allocated to provincial allocable. This portion has 
increased at an average annual rate of 15.2%, and reached PRs10.4 billion in FY2005. 
 
6.  The provincial allocable in Balochistan is shared among the local governments by the 
provincial  finance  commission  (PFC)  according  to  the  governments’  historical  expenditure 
patterns. Such an allocation mechanism is possible because the grants primarily support the

B.  Tuberculosis 
 
7.  Pakistan has the sixth-highest tuberculosis burden among all countries. The incidence of 
tuberculosis  is  determined  through  periodic  tuberculin  and  disease  surveys.  The  overall 
incidence of tuberculosis is 177 cases per 100,000 population, and that of sputum-positive 
pulmonary tuberculosis is 80 cases per 100,000 population, according to a 1987/88 survey.  
 
8.  As  of  2004,  the  Balochistan  department  of  health  had  extended  directly  observed 
therapy  for  tuberculosis  (TB-DOTS)  services  to  23  out  of  27  districts  by  establishing  46 
functional diagnostic and 189 treatment centers. Each functional diagnostic center is to provide 
TB-DOTS services to about 150,000 persons, on average. Its total case load would be about 
270 tuberculosis cases, including 120 sputum-positive cases. Each district has one to three 
diagnostic centers, except Quetta district, which has five centers for its population of 879,000. 
The  population  of  eight  districts  has  been  declared  covered  under  DOTS  with  only  one 
functioning diagnostic center. Case detection for all forms of tuberculosis increased from 1.15% 
in 1998 to 28% in 2004. For sputum-positive cases, the case detection rate for 2004 was 31% 
against a target of 70% for 2005. The case detection rate for new smear-positive cases was 
below 10% in seven districts in 2004. Five of these seven districts have only one functional 
diagnostic center. The sputum conversation rate in 2004 was 88%, the treatment success rate 
81%, and the default rate 12%. The quality assurance system for sputum microscopy is not fully 
established to detect false-positive and false-negative sputum slides.  
 
9.  The tuberculosis control program objectives, in line with national objectives and targets 
set by the World Health Organization (WHO), are to (i) provide DOTS coverage to the entire 
population of the province by 2005; (ii) successfully treat 85% of tuberculosis cases using the 
DOTS strategy and detect 70% of tuberculosis cases by 2005; and (iii) reduce prevalence and 
deaths from tuberculosis by 50% by 2010. The target under Millennium Development Goal 
(MDG) 6 is to halt and begin to reverse the spread of TB by 2015. Two indicators for monitoring 
MDG 6 are: (i) incidence of tuberculosis per 100,000 people; and (ii) proportion of tuberculosis 
cases detected and cured under DOTS. 
 
10.  The  public  sector  health  infrastructure  comprises  40  hospitals  at  various  levels 
(teaching, district and tehsil hospitals), 71 rural health centers, 511 basic health units, 21 
tuberculosis  centers,  and  700  other  lower-level  primary  health  care  (PHC)  facilities 
(dispensaries  and  maternal  and  child  health  centers).  Although  131  health  facilities  (39 
hospitals, 71 rural health centers, and 21 tuberculosis centers) are potentially eligible to become 
diagnostic  centers  for  TB-DOTS,  only  46  functional  diagnostic  centers  provide  so-called 
coverage to the population of 23 districts. The department of health has not been able to make 
even all the tuberculosis centers function as diagnostic centers.  
 
11.  The tuberculosis control program is fully integrated with the health-care system in the 
district governments (DGs), as the health offices of the DGs are responsible for TB-DOTS 
planning  and  implementation.  The  DGs  finance  staff  salaries  and  utility  costs  from  their 
respective district budgets through Account IV but hardly finance any non-salary items, which 
are generally funded by the Balochistan health department from its development budget.

12.  In 2003, the National Tuberculosis Control Program (NTP) received a onetime grant 
from the Global Drug Facility for the procurement of anti-tuberculosis drugs for a period of 2 
years. The drugs are shared with those DG health services where the DOTS strategy is being 
implemented. The stocks are expected to be consumed by 2005 and the provincial government 
or the DGs will have to procure anti-tuberculosis drugs from their own budgets. The NTP has 
also secured grant funds from Global Fund, WHO, and United States Agency for International 
Development (USAID). These funds, invested at the DG level, are intended to support technical
