provincial, and district accounts. The for-profit private sector does not take part in implementing 
the TB-DOTS strategy; instead it uses its own protocols in treating tuberculosis cases. Two 
nongovernment organizations—the Balochistan chapter of the Anti-tuberculosis Association and 
Mercy Corps—are implementing the TB-DOTS strategy in partnership with the public sector 
Tuberculosis Control Program.  
 
13.  The NTP has expanded over time and achieved satisfactory progress. Acceleration 
beyond this level to maintain its 85% treatment success rate and detection rate of up to 70% of 
tuberculosis cases is a daunting task, but it must be done to reverse the spread of tuberculosis 
by 2015. The main challenges faced by the district and provincial program units are: (i) lack of 
doctors and technicians at peripheral facilities, preventing the establishment of diagnostic and 
treatment centers; (ii) absence of linkages between the public sector and the for-profit sector, 
and the limited involvement of the not-for-profit private sector; (iii) lack of resources to establish 
peripheral diagnostic laboratories; (iv) absence of resources to establish referral laboratories for 
quality control; (v) meager non-salary budget at the district level, both for implementation and for 
monitoring; and (vi) geographically dispersed population, separated by long distances. 
 
14.  Options  for  expanding  the  NTP  must  be  found.  DGs  and  the  Balochistan  health 
department  should  explore  the  following  interventions  by  investing  more  resources,  either 
through donor grants or out of their own development budgets: (i) establishing new diagnostic 
centers in the public sector; (ii) establishing new diagnostic and treatment centers in the private 
sector; (iii) training new staff in the DOTS diagnostic and treatment protocols; (iv) establishing 
regional quality control laboratories; (v) expanding TB-DOTS in the remaining four districts; and 
(vi) establishing referral services to deal with complicated cases. 
 
C.  Malaria 
15.  Malaria has been a major public health problem in Balochistan and threatens the health 
of millions of people, especially pregnant women and children under 5 years. Rapid population 
growth, the influx of Afghan refugees, and haphazard urbanization, together with deteriorating 
sanitation has increased malaria incidence in Balochistan. Both Plasmodium falciparum (P.f) 
and  Plasmodium  vivax  (P.v)  types  are  widely  distributed.  The  major  vector  species  are 
Anopheles culicificies and A. stephensi. The major transmission period is from July through 
November, but there is also a short spring transmission during April and May. More recently 
malaria cases have been observed throughout the year in coastal areas, and this is cause for 
concern. 
 
16.  Balochistan province has a high incidence of malaria compared with the rest of the 
country.  The  annual  parasite  incidence  (API)  measures  the  number  of  cases  per  1,000 
population occurring in a year. The overall API for the country was 0.73 per 1,000 in 2001 and 
0.21 per 1,000 in 2004. In Balochistan, API was 9.93, 8.79, 6.69, 7.95, and 6.56 per 1,000 
between 2000 and 2004. A total of 40,730 confirmed cases (32% of all malaria cases in 
Pakistan) were detected in the province by the public sector in 2004. Since about 25% of the 
population uses public sector health facilities, the total number of malaria cases should be at

least four times higher. Therefore, by conservative estimates, about 163,000 cases may occur 
every year at an API of 6.56 per 1,000─a very high morbidity level. In 2004, 35% in Balochistan 
and 26% nationwide had P.f malaria. P.f malaria is generally prevalent in coastal areas, causes 
many deaths in children and results in low-birth-weight babies. In the following 11 high-risk 
districts in the province API has remained quite high in 2002-2003: Kech, Panjgur, Kharan, 
Loralai, Chagai, Ziarat, Zhob, Gawadar, Sibbi, and Jaffarabad. 
 
17.  P.f malaria has become resistant to chloroquine throughout the country. Resistance  
level I (RI) is common (30–84%), RII resistance is rare (2–36%), while resistance level III (RIII) 
has not yet been detected. The upsurge of P. falciparum in Balochistan could be partly due to 
the increase in resistance to chloroquine. Vector resistance to insecticides has been one of the 
major  technical  problems.  Both  malaria  vectors,  i.e.,  A.  culicifacies  and  A.  stephensi,  are 
resistant to organochlorines (DDT, Dieldrin, and BHC). Recently A. stephensi has also become 
resistant to Malathion (organophosphate). The Malaria Control Program now uses Deltamethrin 
(a synthetic pyrethroid) for selective residual indoor spraying to contain focal epidemics. 
 
18.  The objective of the Malaria Control Program, in line with the national objective and 
targets set by WHO for its Rollback Malaria (RBM) program, is to reduce malaria morbidity by 
50% by 2010. The target under MDG 6 is to halt and begin to reverse the spread of malaria by 
2015. Two indicators for monitoring MDG 6 are: (i) prevalence and death rates associated with 
malaria; and (ii) proportion of the population in malaria risk areas that uses effective malaria 
prevention and treatment measures. Three strategies used by the Pakistan Ministry of Health 
and the department of health of Balochistan to reduce malaria morbidity by 50% by 2010 are: 
(i) strengthening preventive, diagnostic, curative, and surveillance services under the devolved 
system; (ii) implementing integrated vector control with the participation of the public and private 
sectors  and  communities;  and  (iii)  increasing  community  awareness  through  appropriate 
measures.  
 
19.  The challenges and gaps in the Balochistan Malaria Control Program are as follows: 
(i) outdated monitoring tools, which were developed in the 1960s and are no longer relevant to 
the RBM strategy; (ii) poorly defined roles and responsibilities at the provincial and district levels 
in the implementation of the RBM strategy in a devolved setting; (iii) high vacancy rate for many 
years among sanctioned posts for field workers; (iv) major funding gaps in community advocacy 
and  mobilization  for  early  diagnosis  and  prevention,  public-private  partnerships  in  early 
diagnosis and prompt treatment, urban malaria prevention and treatment, in-service training of 
health staff (including lady health volunteers) in RBM concepts, provincial and district monitoring 
and supervision, development of peripheral diagnostic facilities in eight districts, preventive 
interventions (like insecticide-treated bed nets) for high-risk malaria districts, periodic preventive 
treatment, and community treatment of children under 5 years; and (v) low awareness among 
the district governments of their financial obligations following devolution, including the funding 
of RBM interventions.

1.  Introduction.  Within  the  framework  of  the  Balochistan  Performance  Grant  Rules 
(BPGR) 2005, performance grants under the Balochistan Devolved Social Services Program 
(BDSSP) will be allocated to district governments (DGs) as non-matching grants to achieve 
progress toward the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in education, health, and water 
supply and sanitation (WSS) and the goals stated in the Balochistan Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Paper (BPRSP).1 
 
2.  Administration Process. The performance grants will be administered according to the 
procedure defined in BPGR 2005; salient features are as follows: (i) public announcement and 
notification by the government of Balochistan; (ii) circulation of the eligibility criteria and contract 
conditions to DGs by the provincial finance commission (PFC) secretariat; (iii) transmission of 
eligibility  certificates  and  documents  from  DGs  to  the  PFC  secretariat;  (iv)  review  of  DG 
documents by the PFC secretariat to check for eligibility and completeness of requirements;  
(v) submission by DGs of any information needed to complete the requirements; (vi) preparation 
of list of eligible DGs, and issuance of invitation to DGs to complete contractual formalities;  
(vii) completion of contractual formalities; (viii) DG submission of monthly expenditure reports 
and quarterly progress reports to PFC; and (ix) monitoring by provincial governments through 
sector line departments. 
 
3.  Distribution  Formula.  The  counterpart  program  funds  generated  from  Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) loan ($65 million) and the ADF grant for the control of HIV/AIDS and 
infectious diseases ($5 million) will be allocated among all eligible DGs as performance grants 
according to a formula established by the PFC.2 
 
4.  Sector Allocations. The performance grants allocated to the DGs will be used for three 
sectors: education, health, and WSS. To conform to national and provincial priorities and ensure 
accurate monitoring, the use of the performance grants will be restricted to the funding areas 
indicated in Table A9, which may be further expanded by the program steering committee. To 
provide flexibility for local needs and ensure sectoral balance, each of the three sectors must be 
allocated at least 20%. The remaining 40% of the DG allocation may be used at their discretion 
in the three social sectors. This would enable them to adopt more effective, demand-driven, and 
participatory planning processes to identify service gaps and rationalize and develop services 
with full ownership.

Contribution of the sectors—education, health, water supply sanitation (WSS)—to the reduction of poverty in 
Balochistan, Pakistan: Geographically, Balochistan is Pakistan’s largest province. Two thirds of its population of 6.5 
million resides in rural areas comprising scattered settlements of sparse populations. The population is ethnically 
diverse, consisting, among others, of Balochi and Pushto speakers. Agriculture is the main source of income for the rural 
population, employing 65% of the total labor force and yielding 60% of the gross provincial domestic product. However, 
only a third of the land area is productive for agricultural or grazing purposes. Half the productive land area is owned by 
10% of large farmers while most tenants work on small farms with incomes below the poverty line. Agricultural 
production and livestock rearing have been seriously damaged by the drought that has prevailed in the province in the 
last 5 years. Poverty in Balochistan increased from an estimated 28.6% in 1993 to 38.4% in 1997. In 2003, the provincial 
government estimated poverty levels at between 41.3% and 47%. Rural poverty is much greater than urban poverty. The 
social  sector  indicators  for  Balochistan  (health,  education,  and  WSS)  also  show  that  the  province  faces  acute 
deprivation. 
 
The Balochistan Provincial Poverty Strategy (BPRS) 2003 and the local government system (implemented in 2001) are 
aimed at facilitating poverty reduction, addressing local needs, and improving public service delivery systems. BPRS is 
geared toward: (i) engendering growth, (ii) managing the scarce water resources, (iii) introducing governance reforms, 
(iv) improving human development, and (v) addressing vulnerability to shocks. The local government system has placed 
local administration under an elected nazim and aims to prioritize in accordance with local needs and to facilitate better 
service delivery. However, while public service delivery systems have improved in some districts, in general the 
functioning of local governments continues to be hampered by incomplete transfer of power and resources, overlapping 
of functions and friction between provincial and local governments as well as between different tiers of local government, 
and  institutional  capacity  gaps.  The  poverty  partnership  between  the  Government  of  Pakistan  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) reflects the Government’s vision for poverty reduction, including the need to improve access 
to and quality of social services for the poor. The Government has agreed that poverty reduction requires good 
governance, increased allocation of funds for social sectors, and improved basic social services to enhance human 
development. ADB supports the Government’s governance reforms through the Decentralization Support Program 
(DSP) and other projects. The Balochistan Devolved Social Services Program (BDSSP) has strong linkages with the 
Balochistan Resource Management Program (BRMP), and supports the aims of the BPRS and the implementation of 
the local government system. 
B.        Poverty Analysis                                 Targeting Classification: Targeted interventions

The “perceptions of poverty” among the poor in Balochistan also go beyond the economic aspect to include political, 
cultural, and institutional dimensions. Poverty in Balochistan also has a distinct spatial dimension, with 24 of its 27 
districts, consisting of 92% of its population, falling under the category of regions of “high” deprivation. Poor households 
in Balochistan are characterized by low levels of education, poor health, and absence of safe drinking water and 
sanitation facilities. Overall, more than half of the total population, of which 78% is female, has never attended school 
because of poverty, social constraints, inaccessibility of schools, lack of basic amenities in educational institutions, and 
poor  quality  of  education  (poor  teaching  methods,  teacher  absenteeism,  etc.).  The  health  indicators  show  that 
malnutrition is rampant among children. Infant and child mortality rates are high, especially among poor households in 
rural areas, and nearly one tenth of infants die before the age of 1 year mainly because of diarrhoeal diseases, perinatal 
diseases, and pneumonia. Immunization coverage is also low.  
 
A very small minority of rural households have access to piped water inside or outside the house. Sixty-three percent of 
the total population, and 72% of the rural population is dependent on unprotected sources for their drinking water. Only 
about a third of the rural population has access to excreta disposal facilities while a negligible proportion has access to a 
sewerage system. Solid waste collection and disposal service is not available to the rural population while only less than 
a third of the urban population has access to this facility. Poverty in Balochistan is also exacerbated by governance 
issues such as strained federal-provincial relations, leading to a general perception of discrimination, neglect, and denial 
of rights; prevalence of a strengthened tribal system that perpetuates the denial of political and fundamental democratic 
rights (especially for women and the poor) and the subjugation of the populace through inordinate influence on the 
system of justice and law enforcement agents; lack of adequate public resources and weak governmental management 
systems; low level of public safety and deteriorating law and order situation, leading to an increased sense of insecurity; 
and the existence of multiple systems of justice, which diminishes the quality of justice available and creates problems 
for those seeking redressal.

During the 1990s, the government implemented the Social Action Program to improve the management and delivery of 
social services. However, this program had very limited success because of lack of political commitment to reforms and 
policies, poor governance, and lack of community involvement.  
 
The goal of BDSSP is to aid Balochistan’s progress toward the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in health, 
education, and WSS. Its objectives are to increase access to affordable, effective, and quality social services  in both 
public and private sectors; reduce disparities in access to services on the basis of gender, ethnicity, income group, and 
regional affiliation; and ensure that strengthened local governments, private sector, and communities improve social 
service delivery. To this end, BDSSP will implement policy reforms and fund local governments to improve service 
delivery and build institutional capacity. The areas of policy reforms include: (i) provincial efficiency incentives—to clarify 
the relationship between provincial and local governments, (ii) managerial power—to strengthen relationship between 
local governments and social service providers, (iii) citizens’ voice and empowerment—to involve citizens in policy 
making and management of social sector facilities, and (iv) private sector engagement. BDSSP will employ the systems 
of “efficient resource management” and allocation of performance grants (developed under BRMP) to local governments 
to ensure the financial sustainability of reforms and to secure the delivery of social services (focusing on the needs of the 
most vulnerable) on a sustainable basis.  
 
BDSSP interventions will be low cost and high impact and will strengthen progress toward the poverty reduction and 
human development targets laid out in the BPRS. Sector strategies will be implemented for health and education (within 
the national and provincial policy framework) and for improvements in sanitation (with the civil society and NGOs). 
Interventions to improve education sector targets and quality of and access to education include refurbishing school 
buildings; upgrading schools (from primary to middle and from middle to high school); providing scholarships for 
deserving  students;  providing  free  textbooks  in  primary  schools;  improving  teaching  methods/learning  materials; 
providing financial support for maintenance and consumables; and forming and strengthening parent teacher school 
management committees (PTSMCs). Improvements in health sector targets and in quality of and access to health 
services will be achieved by implementing interventions for the uplift of district hospitals; addressing the residential 
accommodation needs of hospital and rural health staff; providing grants for the training of local residents and the 
establishment of private practice for private paramedics, dispensers etc.; developing and implementing a hospital 
emergency services plan; and sustaining district hospital boards. The problem of inadequate staff, in both health and 
education facilities, will be addressed by instituting a system of facility-specific non-regularizable contract appointments. 
BDSSP will also involve the private sector and promote public-private partnerships to enhance public service delivery. 
Interventions include developing alternative options for health service delivery in sparsely populated areas; developing 
innovative teaching materials and mother-tongue-based teaching learning materials; and launching a strategy for self-
regulation of the private sector in health and education. Measures to ensure implementation and staff capacity building 
include strengthening of monitoring systems; civil society and third-party monitoring; performance awards for staff and 
service delivery facilities; training of trainers to form a core group of master trainers at the district level for teacher 
training; training of school supervisors; training of head teachers in school management; strengthening of paramedical 
and nursing training schools outside Quetta; and in-service training for health providers.
